snippet.textDisplay:
Everybody already has it, so just live with it. It's not something that's curable, and I'm sure 99.9% of us does not encounter any drastic health issue with it.
In my opinion, to stop using these products just to avoid something that is inevitable to not the best move to play.
So, just take this news as any other news - we learn something new, nothing we can do, honestly nothing too concerning too.
Cheers~ 😊

snippet.textDisplay: The best we can do now (in addition to a global ban on PFAS) is concentration and very high temp incineration of contaminated substances.  Limit exposure - demand a corporately paid recall of all contaminated: carpeting, waterproofing agents, fire retardants, and anything else loaded with PFASs.  Since our county seat manufactures fire extinguishers they tested PFAS extensively and there is a large contamination problem at and near these sites.  Hopefully the risks can at least be minimized, the worst contamination cleaned up.
snippet.textOriginal: The best we can do now (in addition to a global ban on PFAS) is concentration and very high temp incineration of contaminated substances.  Limit exposure - demand a corporately paid recall of all contaminated: carpeting, waterproofing agents, fire retardants, and anything else loaded with PFASs.  Since our county seat manufactures fire extinguishers they tested PFAS extensively and there is a large contamination problem at and near these sites.  Hopefully the risks can at least be minimized, the worst contamination cleaned up.

snippet.textDisplay: PFAS is in the water in my city because we are located near a former dump site. 3M had to pay the state of MN almost $1 billion because of it. My friend’s daughter got a brain tumor from it. They have closed 7 out of 12 wells. It’s still in the other wells but they tell us the levels are “safe”. We have to buy bottled water for everything we do. Vote for people that will protect people and the environment y’all even if that means the price of your non-stick pan will go up by $1.00.

snippet.textDisplay: In general, PFOS and PFOA resist most conventional chemical and microbial treatment technologies. The strongest proven technologies to filter PFAS out of drinking water include granular activated carbon absorption, ion exchange resins and reverse osmosis. There is no way to remove PFAS, the best thing to do is reduce exposure.
snippet.textOriginal: In general, PFOS and PFOA resist most conventional chemical and microbial treatment technologies. The strongest proven technologies to filter PFAS out of drinking water include granular activated carbon absorption, ion exchange resins and reverse osmosis. There is no way to remove PFAS, the best thing to do is reduce exposure.
